text: foreign
the internet's busiest music nerd and
it's time for a review of this new
backwash album his happiness shall come
first even though we are suffering this
is a new LP from Canadian rapper and
producer songwriter backwash her fourth
full-length LP thus far which was
released on her Band Camp Page this past
Halloween surprise considering that some
of her more recent stuff has landed uh
on more formal streaming platforms even
her last one I lie here buried with my
rings and dresses but that's probably
because like her breakthrough album God
has nothing to do with this
um there may be some kind of like not
totally cleared samples on this record
which you can catch yourself listening
to this thing but what I will confirm
about this project is that it is another
crushing and direct collection of songs
that blend together elements of hip-hop
metal Industrial Music this is maybe
backwash's heaviest project yet in fact
but also most versatile thanks to some
new production ID for backwash like on
the track milongo where I've never quite
heard a gospel samples worked into a rat
production that was quite this dark the
perks and synths sound so freaky and
tortured on this cut not to mention on
top of this you have backlash's
trademark snarled wraps she also does an
amazing job of employing these West
African drums and chants on the track
Juju while still keeping to those
booming drums and walls of heavy
distorted tones that kind of Define her
songs for the most part make them a more
enveloping experience also the
appearance from guy scuver on the front
end of the track is especially good one
of the best features here there are
other guest appearances that kind of
make these tracks as well like on
ziggalo where rappers sensor dialogue as
well as sadistic bring various themes of
God's Wrath abuse fear which are all
backed up by backwash as well I would
say this track is one of her biggest
indulgences in the horrorcore genre
especially with the rising and chilling
orchestrations that build up in the
final leg the track is devilish and
Powerful there are some vein popping
screams Oliver nayema thanks to a guest
vocal from pupil slicer which gives
those droning guitar riffs and pounding
drums a certain level of extremity the
lyrics on this track very much match the
vibe as well many of the bars dealing in
backwash having a gun on her for
protection as a black Trans woman who is
statistically more likely to suffer a
hate crime of some sort and there have
been whiffs of these similarly paranoid
themes on previous backwash albums but
this track really kind of focuses in on
them in a scarily intense way to
compound this there's the horrifying
mizungu who's beat or resembles that of
like an early Death Grips uh production
but maybe with a more metal twist
backwash opens things up with a pretty
notable Malcolm X quote and kind of
launches off of those themes into a few
verses about racial hatred self-hatred
seeing evil in oneself there are other
relatively experimental ideas on the
record though not every one of them pans
out in my opinion there's nafwiti for
example who's three four time signature
and kind of descending falsetto vocal
passages come across a little grating to
the point where I think the horror of
the track is trying to instill doesn't
quite land though not every moment on
this record is out there by backwash
standards some of the best tracks kind
of feel like a slightly elevated version
of things that we've heard in the past
the factory floor drums and impenetrable
walls of distortion and bass on komoto
make this track maybe the most
suffocating industrial hip-hop song
backwash has ever done meanwhile vivonda
which helps kick the record off feels
like a twisted and demonic prayer set to
these immense classical samples and
really epic chord changes on the back
end that hit pretty hard just bringing a
sense of urgency and Harmony refinement
that I haven't heard in a lot of
backwash tracks previously but then
mukazi is maybe the most interesting
closer to finish off any backwash record
so far it's kind of a Sentimental and
uplifting moment a ray of light in a way
where she effectively reflects on
everything that has brought her up to
this point the neighborhood she was
raised in friends family members she's
forgiving as well as her struggles with
impression which are all soundtracked by
these really classy old school Soul
samples and yeah this is handily the
most touching Moment On Any backwash
album so far and it kind of works
perfectly despite this Vibe not really
being what you typically kind of expect
from her but yeah overall uh pretty
impressed with this record backwash
comes through with another Banger this
one hits hard it's dark it's Grim
um there are some slight improvements in
intensity and uh Variety in terms of
samples and sound palette and so on and
so forth but in some respects
compositionally I will say she is uh
painting herself into a bit of a corner
even if again I do kind of hear these
improvements in terms of like lyrical
focus and you know production ideas and
you know throwing things for a loop a
little bit on the production and
emotional end with the closer so yeah
the songs are solid the performances and
writing are solid there are enough
attempts to kind of switch things up and
improve things and Advance things to
keep things into interesting but could
there have been more risks taken across
this record especially since a lot of
the sounds on this LP are pretty well
established from the previous two
backwash efforts yeah I think so still
even with that being said I'm feeling a
strong seven to a light eight on this
one transition have you given this
record a listen did you love it did you
hate it what would you rate it you're
the best you're the best what should I
review next hit the like if you like
Please Subscribe and please don't cry
hit the Bell as well over here next to
my head is another video that you can
check out hit that up or the link to
subscribe to the channel Anthony fantana
backwash forever
